items.title: Fusion power has a fuel problem; Hexium has a laser-powered solution
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Fusion startups face significant challenges, including creating a sustainable power plant and sourcing fuel.
- Tritium, a key ingredient for fusion, is derived from lithium, which is currently in short supply.
- Hexium, founded by Charlie Jerrott and Jacob Peterson, aims to solve this fuel problem using atomic vapor laser isotope separation (AVLIS) technology.
- The company has raised $8 million in seed funding and plans to build a pilot plant to produce lithium-6, which is necessary for tritium fuel.
- Their process requires low-power lasers tuned to interact specifically with lithium-6, allowing for efficient separation from lithium-7.
- Hexium's modular design strategy allows for scaled production without the need for large facilities.

items.title: Phantom Neuro grabs $19M to help amputees put their phantom limbs to use
Apple details how it plans to improve its AI models by privately analyzing user data
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple is addressing criticism regarding its AI products by analyzing user data privately.
- The company will use a method called "differential privacy" to generate synthetic data for model improvement.
- Synthetic data mimics user data but doesn't include actual user content, allowing for more accurate AI model training.
- Apple aims to enhance its AI capabilities in features like email summaries and various writing tools using this approach.

items.title: Waymo and Uber prepare to launch robotaxi service in Atlanta this summer
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Uber invites customers in Atlanta to sign up for a Waymo robotaxi service.
- The robotaxi service is set to launch in Atlanta this summer.
- Uber and Waymo previously announced plans for robotaxi services in Austin and Atlanta in early 2025.
- Uber handles vehicle management while Waymo oversees the autonomous technology and operations.
- Only Uber users can hail the fleet of Jaguar I-PACE vehicles.
- The service will cover 65 square miles of Atlanta initially, with plans for future expansion.
- Customers signing up will receive updates and may gain early access to the service.

items.title: Girls Who Code founder Reshma Saujani spills business tea with Meghan, Duchess of Sussex
items.summary:
- Reshma Saujani, founder of Girls Who Code, discussed her journey on Meghan's podcast, "Confessions of a Female Founder."
- Saujani admitted her lack of coding experience but successfully launched Girls Who Code, training over 670,000 individuals in STEM.
- The podcast aims to inspire social entrepreneurship and share female founders' experiences while navigating business and motherhood.

items.title: Marshmallow, the UK insurance startup for migrants, raises $90M at a $2B+ valuation
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- U.K. startup [Marshmallow](https://www.marshmallow.com/) raises $90 million to expand its services, valued over $2 billion.
- The startup has insured 1 million drivers, reporting an annual revenue run rate of $500 million, focusing on car insurance for migrants.
- Marshmallow aims to diversify into financial services and additional insurance products, helping migrants integrate into life in the U.K.
- CEO Oliver Kent-Braham highlights the growing migrant population, with 1.2 million arrivals in 2024.
- The funding consists of equity and debt, led by Portage Capital, with participation from BlackRock and others.
- Marshmallow previously raised funding at a $1.25 billion valuation in 2021, having grown from 100,000 insured individuals to a million.
- The startup's strategy aims to be a 'one-stop shop' for insurance and financial products for new arrivals.

items.title: RLWRLD raises $14.8M to build a foundational model for robotics
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- South Korean startup RLWRLD has raised 21 billion KRW (about $14.8 million) in seed funding.
- The funding round was led by Hashed and involves several strategic investors including LG Electronics and SK Telecom.
- RLWRLD aims to automate manual tasks using a foundational AI model that combines large language models with robotics software.
- The startup plans to fund proof-of-concept projects, secure computing infrastructure, and hire research talent.
- They aim to develop advanced robotic capabilities like five-finger movements, surpassing current competitors.
- The company also explores automating human-centric workflows with demonstrations planned for later this year.

items.title: Debates over AI benchmarking have reached Pokémon
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A social media post claimed Google’s Gemini model outperformed Anthropic’s Claude model in the original Pokémon games.
- Gemini reportedly reached Lavender Town during a developer Twitch stream, while Claude was still at Mount Moon.
- Benefits of custom minimaps for AI gameplay influence benchmarking results, raising concerns about fair comparison in AI model evaluations.
- Previous AI scores from Anthropic and Meta highlighted the disparities in performance based on custom implementations for benchmarks.
- Custom benchmarks like Pokémon, while popular, are not reliable indicators of a model’s overall capabilities.

items.title: Lime’s scooter and e-bike batteries will be recycled by Redwood Materials
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Lime has partnered with Redwood Materials for battery recycling from its scooters and e-bikes.
- Redwood will recover lithium, cobalt, nickel, and copper for reuse in battery manufacturing.
- The partnership covers Lime’s operations in the US, Germany, and the Netherlands but not all regions.
- This is Lime’s first direct relationship with a North American battery recycler.
- Lime aims to decarbonize its business by 2030 and has reduced emissions by 59.5% since 2019.
- Andrew Savage, VP of Sustainability at Lime, highlighted the collaboration’s role in closing the supply chain loop.
- Redwood has partnerships with other companies, including Lyft, for e-bike battery recycling.

items.title: Rippling is trying to serve Deel’s CEO, but bailiffs can’t find him
items.summary:
- HR tech startup Rippling is attempting to serve Deel CEO Alex Bouaziz with legal papers amid a lawsuit against Deel.
- French bailiffs hired by Rippling are unable to locate Bouaziz at his Paris address.
- Rippling's lawsuit claims Deel paid an employee to spy on them, while Deel denies all wrongdoing.
- Bouaziz is described as 'highly nomadic' and lists different locations on LinkedIn and X (formerly Twitter).
- Rippling may consider serving Bouaziz via email due to ongoing difficulties in locating him.

items.title: Chinese marketplace DHgate becomes a top US app as trade war intensifies
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- The DHgate app surged to No. 3 in the U.S. Apple App Store due to viral TikTok videos explaining luxury goods' origins amid rising tariffs.
- Following a 145% tariff increase on Chinese imports by Trump, downloads of DHgate rose significantly, with 117,500 installs on iOS alone on April 13.
- The trend highlighted U.S. consumers' dependence on Chinese manufacturing, with TikTok creators revealing that many perceived luxury items originate in China before being labeled in Europe.

items.title: Meet Neptune, a TikTok alternative where creators can hide likes and follower counts
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Neptune is a new short-form video app aiming to compete with TikTok, Instagram Reels, and YouTube Shorts.
- The app is currently in beta with 970 testers and 400,000 people on the waitlist.
- Set to launch on the App Store next week, with a Google Play Store rollout in approximately six months.
- Founded by Ashley Darling, former talent director, focusing on creativity rather than follower counts.
- Allows creators to hide likes and follower counts, reducing pressure while still providing optional visibility for metrics.
- Emphasizes user interests and content quality through its algorithm.
- Features include a video feed, discovery tools, and a “Hop Back” function for resuming videos.
- Future updates will introduce livestreaming capabilities, playlist creation, and music integrations.

items.title: Hertz says customers’ personal data and driver’s licenses stolen in data breach
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- Hertz reported a data breach involving customers' personal data and driver's licenses due to a cyberattack on a vendor between October 2024 and December 2024.
- Affected data includes names, dates of birth, contact information, driver's licenses, and payment card information; Social Security numbers and other IDs were also compromised for some customers.
- At least 3,400 customers in Maine were confirmed affected; the total number is likely much higher, but no specific estimates were provided.

items.title: OpenAI’s new GPT-4.1 AI models focus on coding
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched GPT-4.1, including variants mini and nano, optimized for coding tasks.
- Features a 1-million-token context window, capable of processing 750,000 words in one input.
- Competes against models from Google and Anthropic, aiming to develop sophisticated coding capabilities.
- GPT-4.1 costs $2 per million input tokens and $8 per million output tokens; mini and nano are cheaper but less accurate.
- Achieved scores of 52% to 54.6% on SWE-bench Verified, falling short of competitors Google and Anthropic.
- GPT-4.1 performed 72% accuracy in Video-MME tests for video content understanding.
- Acknowledged limitations include reliability issues with high token input and vulnerability to bugs in generated code.

items.title: OpenAI plans to phase out GPT-4.5, its largest-ever AI model, from its API
Google’s newest AI model is designed to help study dolphin ‘speech’
items.summary:
- Google DeepMind developed an AI model named DolphinGemma to decipher dolphin vocalizations.
- The model aids research on dolphin communication and was trained using data from the Wild Dolphin Project.
- DolphinGemma can produce ‘dolphin-like’ sound sequences and is efficient enough to operate on smartphones.
- The Wild Dolphin Project plans to utilize the Google Pixel 9 for generating and matching dolphin vocalizations this summer, enhancing their research capabilities.

items.title: Google Classroom gives teachers an AI feature for quiz questions
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Google Classroom introduced a new AI-powered feature for generating quiz questions, launched on April 14, 2025.
- Teachers can input text manually or upload files from Google Drive for the AI to create questions, which can then be exported to Google Docs or Forms.
- The feature allows customization based on grade level, question type, and desired skills for students, available only to Google Workspace for Education subscribers with specific add-ons.

items.title: Blue Origin’s all-female crew, including Katy Perry, successfully launched
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Blue Origin launched its New Shepard rocket with the first all-female crew since 1963 on April 14, 2025, at 9:30 a.m. ET.
- The crew included Katy Perry, Gayle King, Kerianne Flynn, Lauren Sánchez, Amanda Nguyen, and Aisha Bowe.
- The mission aimed to highlight women's roles in astronautics despite criticism regarding exclusivity in space tourism.

items.title: Chipolo’s newest AirTag competitor works with both Apple and Google’s finding networks
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Chipolo introduced a new version of its product, Chipolo POP, compatible with both Apple and Google’s finding networks.
- This change allows easier gifting as buyers don’t need to check device compatibility.
- Chipolo has sold over 4.5 million devices and experienced a 30% average annual growth since launching its first ‘Find My’ compatible products.
- The device offers features like a user-replaceable battery, a 300-foot Bluetooth range, and various color options. The price is $29.

items.title: Meta to start training its AI models on public content in the EU
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Meta announced it will train its AI models on public content from Facebook and Instagram in the EU starting this week.
- This move follows a previous pause due to regulatory pressure over data privacy concerns, specifically GDPR.
- Users will receive notifications about the data use and can opt out; private messages and data from users under 18 will not be used for training.
- The company aims to better understand European dialects and nuances by using diverse public data.
- The decision aligns Meta with similar practices by Google and OpenAI, which have used European user data for AI training.

items.title: Hugging Face buys a humanoid robotics startup
items.author: Matthieu Lapeyre, Pierre Rouanet
items.summary:
- AI development platform Hugging Face has acquired French startup Pollen Robotics for an undisclosed amount.
- The acquisition focuses on the humanoid robot Reachy 2, which will be available for developers to improve and modify its code.
- Pollen Robotics, founded in 2016, previously raised €2.5 million for its goal of creating affordable humanoid robots for homes.
- Hugging Face's acquisition is part of its broader robotics efforts, having previously collaborated with Pollen on an open-source robot project.

items.title: Autonomous trucking startup Kodiak Robotics to go public via SPAC
Silicon Valley crosswalk buttons hacked to imitate Musk, Zuckerberg’s voices
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- Audio-enabled crosswalk buttons in Silicon Valley were hacked to imitate the voices of Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk.
- Videos showed buttons in Menlo Park, Palo Alto, and Redwood City playing AI-generated speech.
- The hack was speculated to be an act of hacktivism; the city is investigating the issue.

items.title: Nvidia says it plans to manufacture some AI chips in the U.S.
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Nvidia is developing over a million square feet of manufacturing space in Arizona and Texas for AI chips.
- Production of Nvidia Blackwell chips has begun at TSMC’s facilities in Phoenix, and new supercomputer plants are being built with partners Foxconn and Wistron.
- Mass production is expected to ramp up in 12-15 months, with plans to produce AI infrastructure worth up to $500 billion in the U.S. and create numerous jobs.

items.title: Conifer locks down $20M seed round for its ‘drop-in’ electric hub motor
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Conifer, a startup founded by former Lucid Motors and Apple engineers, raises $20M seed round.
- Developed a drop-in electric hub motor using abundant ferrite magnets, avoiding rare earth elements.
- Motor design offers higher efficiency, is smaller, and aims to alleviate supply chain risks.
- Targets small mobility market, including on- and off-road vehicles, lawnmowers, and HVAC systems.
- Plans to ship production motors later this year with several global customers already showing interest.
- Conifer's approach localizes supply chains and automates manufacturing for safer and complex processes.

items.title: Intel agrees to sell controlling stake in Altera chip business
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Intel has entered a definitive agreement to sell 51% of its Altera semiconductor business to Silver Lake for $8.75 billion.
- Altera will become operationally independent, retaining 49% ownership by Intel.
- Raghib Hussain will succeed Sandra Rivera as CEO on May 5, 2025.
- Altera was acquired by Intel in 2015 for $16.7 billion and is now spinning off with intentions for an IPO in the next three years.
- The FPGA market is projected to grow from $12.1 billion to $25.8 billion by 2029.
- Altera generated revenues of $1.54 billion in fiscal year 2024.
- The transaction is expected to close in the second half of 2025, pending customary conditions.

items.title: Bill Gates-backed Arnergy to expand solar access in Nigeria with $18M as demand surges
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Demand for solar energy in Nigeria has surged due to worsening grid reliability and rising fuel costs.
- Arnergy raised a total of $18 million in a Series B financing to expand its solar solutions.
- The removal of Nigeria’s fuel subsidy in May 2023 caused petrol prices to rise nearly 500%, increasing the cost-effectiveness of solar solutions.
- Arnergy's lease-to-own product, Z Lite, is gaining popularity as it offers affordability compared to rising electricity tariffs and costs of petrol and diesel generators.
- Arnergy has deployed over 1,800 systems across Nigeria and plans to install more than 12,000 systems by 2029.
- A proposed ban on solar panel imports may threaten Arnergy's growth, emphasizing the need for local manufacturing capacity before imposing such restrictions.

items.title: UK founders grow frustrated over dearth of funding: ‘the problem is getting worse’
items.summary:
- British start-ups raised only £16.2 billion in 2024, significantly less than over £65 billion raised by Silicon Valley counterparts.
- The U.S. received 57% of global venture capital funding, marking a trend where U.K. founders are considering relocating abroad.
- Founders like Mati Staniszewski and Barney Hussey-Yeo express frustrations over the lack of capital in the U.K., indicating a worsening situation.

items.title: Access to future AI models in OpenAI’s API may require a verified ID
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI may require organizations to complete an ID verification process to access future AI models, as stated on a recently published support page.
- The new verification process called Verified Organization will require a government-issued ID from supported countries, with restrictions on the eligibility of organizations and the frequency of verifications.
- This move aims to ensure responsible AI usage and mitigate violations of usage policies, particularly focusing on preventing malicious use and IP theft.

items.title: Apple reportedly working on a Vision Pro that plugs into your Mac
items.summary:
- Apple is not abandoning the Vision Pro mixed reality headset despite disappointing sales.
- The company is reportedly working on two new models: a lighter and cheaper version to address initial complaints.
- A separate model will allow connectivity to Macs for streaming content and enterprise applications.
- CEO Tim Cook aims to create lightweight augmented reality glasses suitable for all-day wear.

items.title: Tech tariff exemptions are only temporary, according to Trump’s commerce secretary
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick states that recent exemptions on tech tariffs are temporary.
- The Trump administration announced exemptions for consumer electronics like laptops and smartphones, but a 10% baseline tariff remains.
- Targeted tariffs on semiconductors, expected in one to two months, may affect these exempted products.
- Lutnick aims for increased American manufacturing of semiconductors and related products to reduce reliance on foreign production.
- Trump indicated he will provide more information about semiconductor tariffs soon.

items.title: Jack Dorsey and Elon Musk would like to ‘delete all IP law’
Jim Zemlin on Taking a ‘Portfolio Approach’ to Linux Foundation Projects
items.author: Jim Zemlin
items.summary:
- The Linux Foundation has evolved into a broad organization supporting numerous open source projects beyond its original focus on the Linux kernel.
- Jim Zemlin emphasizes a 'portfolio approach' for diverse technological support, recognizing the need for a collective investment across various projects.
- Recent collaborations, like with the OpenInfra Foundation, enhance the Linux Foundation’s ability to tackle regulatory and compliance challenges collectively.
- The Linux Foundation is adapting to the rise of AI, interpreting it as a significant moment for open source, akin to previous technological breakthroughs.
- Zemlin views the Linux Foundation's efforts similar to a 'reverse venture capitalist' approach, focusing on project-market fit rather than profit, aiming for impactful technological contributions instead.

items.title: Could an Amazon driver could be the one who saves your life?
items.summary:
- Amazon is transitioning from a merchandising giant to a healthcare player through initiatives like Project Pulse.
- Project Pulse involved equipping delivery vans with defibrillators and training drivers in CPR in cities like London, Amsterdam, and Bologna.
- Amazon is evaluating feedback from the pilot program and considering future opportunities as it expands its healthcare ambitions while competitors retreat from primary care.

items.title: Apple’s ‘Mythic Quest’ is ending with an updated Season 4 finale
items.summary:
- "Mythic Quest" on Apple TV+ is concluding after four seasons.
- A new version of the fourth season finale, which aired on March 26, will premiere with an updated ending next week.
- Executive producers Megan Ganz, David Hornsby, and Rob McElhenney confirmed the change was made with Apple’s consent to properly conclude the series.

items.title: OpenAI co-founder Ilya Sutskever’s Safe Superintelligence reportedly valued at $32B
Cofertility’s radical model for women: Freeze your eggs for free by donating half of them
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Cofertility offers women the option to freeze their eggs for free by donating half the retrieved eggs to those unable to conceive.
- The startup raised a $7.25 million Series A round, bringing total funding to $16 million.
- Cofertility aims to remove the taboo of egg donation and solve structural problems in accessing donor eggs.

items.title: Trump exempts smartphones, laptops, and semiconductors from new tariffs
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- The Trump administration has announced tariff exemptions for the tech industry, including smartphones and laptops.
- A universal baseline 10% tariff will remain while tariffs on Chinese goods rise to 125%.
- U.S. Customs and Border Protection published a list of product categories excluded from tariffs, effective from April 5, including semiconductors.
- Tech companies like Apple and Nvidia are likely to benefit from these exemptions.
- There may be upcoming investigations related to semiconductors under national security concerns.

items.title: Week in Review: Jeff Bezos’ secret EV startup
items.author: Karyne Levy
items.summary:
- Jeff Bezos is backing Slate, an EV startup aiming to create a two-seater pickup truck priced at $25,000, with production expected by late 2026.
- Meta whistleblower Sarah Wynn-Williams testified that the company colluded with the Chinese Communist Party to undermine U.S. national security.
- Trevor Milton, former Nikola founder recently pardoned for securities fraud, is attempting to purchase Nikola's bankrupt assets.
- Waymo plans to use interior camera data from its robotaxis to train AI models, with options for users to opt out.
- President Trump signed an executive order endorsing coal as power for data centers, aiming to designate it as a critical mineral.
- Hacked documents from NetJets revealed insights into serving Elon Musk, noting his preference for quick, un-conservative flight schedules.

items.title: The xAI–X merger is a good deal — if you’re betting on Musk’s empire
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI acquires social media company X (formerly Twitter) in an all-stock deal.
- The deal is seen as strategic for Musk to enhance his narrative of success and integrate AI capabilities with real-time data from X.
- Musk's ventures are interconnected, with investments across companies like Tesla and SpaceX creating an 'Elon ecosystem'.
- Concerns exist over the valuation of X at $33 billion and xAI at $80 billion amid little reported revenue.
- Investors remain optimistic about the long-term potential of Musk’s companies despite risks, including SEC lawsuits and regulatory challenges.

items.title: Forerunner’s long game: As startups stall before IPO, all options are on the table
items.author: Connie Loizos
items.summary:
- Forerunner Ventures has supported startups like Warby Parker, Bonobos, and Glossier, which have not followed traditional IPO paths.
- Forerunner founder Kirsten Green states that alternatives to traditional IPOs are now the norm, reflecting a shift in market strategies.
- Companies like Chime and Ōura have significant valuations but differ in their IPO readiness, with Chime having confidentially filed to go public.
- The secondary market is gaining importance, allowing firms to manage liquidity and exposure more effectively.
- Green emphasizes the need for patience in venture capital, as not all growth paths are immediate or traditional IPOs.

items.title: Meta’s vanilla Maverick AI model ranks below rivals on a popular chat benchmark
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Meta faced backlash for using an experimental version of Llama 4 Maverick to manipulate scores in LM Arena.
- The unmodified version of Maverick ranks below other models like OpenAI’s GPT-4o and Anthropic’s Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
- The experimental version was optimized for conversationality, which contributed to its lower performance on established benchmarks.

items.title: The most interesting startups showcased at Google Cloud Next
Meta adds Stripe CEO Patrick Collison and Dina Powell McCormick to its board
Law professors side with authors battling Meta in AI copyright case
38 consumer startup founders lobby over Trump tariffs: One faces a surprise $200K bill
items.author: Allison Luvera, Rebecca Minkoff, Alison Wyatt, Emily Doyle, Mei Kwok, Yanghee Paik
items.summary:
- 38 female consumer product founders warn that small businesses could suffer from increased tariffs under Trump.
- Trump's 90-day tariff pause sets rate at 10%, but tariffs on China are raised to 145%.
- Founders request Congress to halt tariff increases until small businesses find affordable supply chain alternatives, or at least provide exemptions for them.
- Allison Luvera faces a surprise $200,000 bill due to overseas packaging sourcing and lacking U.S. options.
- The group generates $800 million annually and employs thousands, stating tariffs disproportionately affect small businesses.
- They are lobbying for a small business assessment and seeking grants, tax incentives, or assistance to ease supply chain issues.

items.title: TechCrunch Mobility: Jeff Bezos backs a secretive EV startup and Lucid snaps up Nikola’s assets
Nikola founder Trevor Milton accused of trying to derail bankruptcy case
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Trevor Milton, founder of Nikola, is accused of attempting to interfere in the company's bankruptcy proceedings.
- A court approved the sale of Nikola's assets to Lucid Motors, but Milton's attorney raised concerns about the auction process.
- Milton was previously pardoned by President Trump and may challenge a $168 million arbitration award he owes Nikola.
- Nikola settled a class action lawsuit by shareholders due to false claims made by Milton during his tenure as CEO.
- The ongoing actions from Milton are believed to potentially harm Nikola's asset sale and overall recovery efforts.

items.title: Blue Water Autonomy comes out of stealth promising autonomous naval ships
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Blue Water Autonomy is a new startup emerging from stealth focused on developing autonomous naval ships.
- Founded in 2024 by former U.S. Navy members and leaders from Amazon Robotics and iRobot.
- The Boston-based company has raised $14 million in seed funding from Eclipse VC, Riot, and Impatient Ventures.
- Plans include developing a full-stack autonomy suite and concept ship designs; currently testing a 100-ton autonomous vessel off Boston.
- The funding will be used to expand the engineering team and accelerate testing processes.

items.title: Ex-OpenAI staffers file amicus brief opposing the company’s for-profit transition
items.author: Steven Adler, Rosemary Campbell, Neil Chowdhury, Jacob Hilton, Daniel Kokotajlo, Gretchen Krueger, Todor Markov, Richard Ngo, Girish Sastry, William Saunders, Carrol Wainwright, Jeffrey Wu
items.summary:
- A group of ex-OpenAI employees filed an amicus brief supporting Elon Musk’s lawsuit against OpenAI's transition from non-profit to for-profit.
- The brief cites twelve former staffers and argues that surrendering control to a for-profit violates OpenAI’s mission.
- OpenAI maintains that its nonprofit remains intact and that the for-profit transition will form a public benefit corporation (PBC).
- Musk's lawsuit claims OpenAI abandoned its commitment to ensure AI benefits all humanity; a federal judge allowed the case to proceed to trial in 2026.
- The brief warns the transition might lead OpenAI to prioritize shareholder profits over safety, undermining its original governance structure.
